prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for wearing earbuds and occasionally checking my phone during a church mass that I am forced to go to even though I am an atheist?
My parents have recently had a interest in going to church for the past month or so, so every Sunday, they force me to attend mass with them. I have told them multiple times that I don't believe in what they believe, but they brush it off and force me to come anyways. So this time, I brought earbuds and put on an album to listen to (Stokeley by Ski Mask the Slump God is great; listen to it) because I wanted to listen to my music instead. I would also text my friend every 15 minutes or so. During the entire mass, my mom shot me dirty looks the whole time and later told me on the ride home that I have a horribly negative attitude and that I should enjoy things more (even though I have told them countless times that I don't believe in what they do and dislike attending church.

Am I just being a bitch or are my parents at fault?
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user wants to know if the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong for using earbuds and texting during church. The author is an atheist forced to attend mass with their parents. They mentioned they've told their parents about their disbelief but they still make them come. The parents are upset, especially the mom, who gave dirty looks and criticized the author's attitude.

Hmm, first, the parents are making the child attend church against their beliefs. The author is trying to cope by listening to music and texting. Is this the author's fault? Well, the parents are forcing the child to be in a place that's uncomfortable for them. The author isn't doing anything illegal or morally wrong by using earbuds or texting. They're just trying to manage the time they're forced to spend there. The parents might view it as disrespectful, but if the child isn't in the religion, maybe they don't have the same expectations. The parents seem to be the ones forcing the situation, so the author's actions are a reaction to that. The main issue is the parents' insistence on their child attending despite their beliefs. So the author isn't in the wrong. Answer B.
